headline: CORN SLIDES, WHEAT RALLIES AS CLASSIC WRAPS
subheadline: Front-month corn drops over 1% while Chicago wheat surges on renewed export interest.
lead: Corn took it on the chin Friday, with the front month settling at 438.75 — down 1.13% — while new-crop December held up better at 469.50. Chicago wheat was the standout, rallying 2.51% to 591.25. Soybeans softened modestly, but the real pressure hit soybean meal, down over 2%.
teaser: Wheat surges, corn slides, and Commodity Classic delivers tech buzz — here's your Saturday snapshot.

one_number.context: Wheat's sharp rally signals potential export demand revival and could pull row crop acres into the conversation.

sections.title: GRAINS & OILSEEDS
sections.body: Front-month corn at 438.75 lost over five cents on the session, but the December 2026 contract edged up to 469.50 — watch that carry for storage signals. Soybeans at 1157.25 slipped 0.71%, with meal taking the harder hit at 315.50. Wheat's 2.51% pop to 591.25 is the number that matters — if it holds Monday, expect spillover chatter on spring planting intentions.

sections.title: WEATHER & FIELD CONDITIONS
sections.body: Central Illinois sits at 48°F under overcast skies with almost no moisture in the forecast — just 2% precip chance and zero inches over the last three days. That's decent for any fieldwork that needs doing, but soil temps remain a non-factor until mid-March. No spray windows to worry about today; enjoy the dry weekend.

sections.title: MARKETS & MACRO
sections.body: Live cattle ripped 2.96% to 244.00 — feedlot margins are getting interesting. Crude oil jumped 2.62% to 67.02, which puts a floor under input costs. The dollar index slipped to 97.565, mildly supportive for exports. Ten-year yields dropped to 3.96%, signaling markets still betting on a soft landing.

watch_list.desc: Commodity Classic 2026 final sessions — announcements on tech and input pricing.
USDA weekly export sales Thursday — wheat demand confirmation is key.
South American harvest pressure continues; Brazil's second-crop corn on pace.
Wheat rally could extend if Black Sea logistics tighten; new-crop beans look undervalued.
